problems.problem: A spaceship moves at $0.8c$ relative to Earth. What is the time interval of 10 s on the spaceship as measured by an observer on Earth?
problems.final_answer: Time interval measured on Earth is approximately $16.67\,\text{s}$.

problems.problem: A rod of proper length $L_0 = 5\,\text{m}$ moves at $0.6c$ relative to an observer. What is its observed length?
An astronaut measures a distance of 12 light-years to a star. What is this distance in the frame of Earth if the star moves at $0.9c$ relative to Earth?
problems.final_answer: Distance in Earth's frame is approximately $27.5\,\text{light-years}$.

problems.problem: Two events occur 3 × 10^(-6) s apart in one frame. If they are separated by 600 m in space, what is the time interval in a frame moving at $0.8c$ along the line connecting the events?
problems.final_answer: Time interval in moving frame is approximately $2.33 \times 10^{-6}\,\text{s}$.

problems.problem: A particle has a rest mass of 2 kg and moves at $0.6c$. Calculate its relativistic mass.
An observer sees a particle moving at $0.9c$ with a momentum of 27 kg·m/s. Calculate its rest mass.
problems.final_answer: Rest mass of the particle is approximately $13.1\,\text{kg}$.

problems.problem: Two spaceships move towards each other at $0.7c$ relative to Earth. Calculate their speed relative to each other.
problems.final_answer: Speed of one spaceship relative to the other is approximately $0.939c$.

problems.problem: A light pulse travels 1.5 × 10^8 m. How long does it take according to an observer in the same frame?
Explain why no object with mass can reach the speed of light.

step_by_step.explanation: As speed approaches $c$, relativistic mass $m = m_0 / \sqrt{1 - v^2/c^2} \to \infty$, requiring infinite energy.

problems.final_answer: Objects with mass cannot reach the speed of light because infinite energy would be required.

problems.problem: A muon has a rest lifetime of 2.2 μs and moves at $0.998c$. Calculate its lifetime as measured by a laboratory observer.
problems.final_answer: Muon lifetime in lab frame is approximately $3.48 \times 10^{-5}\,\text{s}$.
